Subject: New HyperNEAT Paper with Extensive Substrate Visualizations
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=Hj971JZi0w8LZ8Yghla2EyeHAN9eKFcnwt4sz9mUChUk02YKU-mj

Jason Gauci and I are very pleased to share with you our recently accepted =
article (to appear) in Neural Computation journal, "Autonomous Evolution of=
 Topographic Regularities in Artificial Neural Networks."

http://eplex.cs.=
ucf.edu/publications/2010/gauci.nc10.html

Direct link: http://eplex.cs.ucf=
.edu/papers/gauci_nc10.pdf

While this paper revisits the checkers results =
from our 2008 AAAI conference paper, it includes extensive analysis that ha=
s never been published before.  This analysis is particularly interesting b=
ecause it reveals geometric properties of connectivity patterns that are co=
rrelated to good generalization.  In particular, what we found is that the =
smoothness of a connectivity pattern is correlated to the generality of its=
 play, which you can see for yourself in the paper.  

I think this result =
is interesting because smoothness is itself a geometric property.  In other=
 words, the only efficient way to describe a smooth pattern is to describe =
it within some geometry.  If it is true that geometric smoothness is a gene=
rally important property of topographic connectivity patterns, then it sugg=
ests that approaches outside indirect encoding, including outside of evolut=
ionary computation, face a daunting challenge with generalization because t=
hey have no way to express graceful gradation and regularity across a geome=
try.

At the same time, it gives some deeper insight into why HyperNEAT is =
performing so well in this domain and where it can be expected to excel in =
general.

ken
